intro: Hyssopus alopecuroides, commonly known as narrow-leaved hyssop, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, narrow, and slightly hairy leaves. Its small, tubular flowers are usually blue to purple in color and bloom in the summer months. This species is often used in traditional herbal medicine and as a decorative plant in gardens.
